attributes.action: Prohibit the Sale/Use of Glue Traps in the UK
attributes.background: Current legislation states that glue traps are legal to use and the onus is on the user to ensure they're only used as a last resort, and that they're checked regularly so that any animals caught can be humanely killed. This needs to be reviewed and the sale and use of glue traps should be banned.
attributes.additional_details:
It's impossible to regulate the use of these traps, and any amount of time an animal is stuck to the trap it will be suffering. It will likely die of starvation or stress before it's discovered to be killed. 

Whilst the traps are designed for rodents they are indiscriminate; other wildlife and even pets have been injured or killed after becoming trapped.

The only solution is a total ban on the sale or use of glue traps.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petition:

Make glue traps illegal within the UK
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/560288

attributes.action: Save The Derwent Walk in Tyne & Wear, County Durham from Railway development
attributes.background: There have been plans released to convert the Derwent Walk spanning across Gateshead and Durham back into a railway line, we want this stopped in its tracks! There has been a £65k grant from Durham City Council for a feasibility study.
attributes.additional_details: There has been no public consultation for this & the local MP has and will not disclose any data from the survey. To destroy such a beautiful piece of culture and beauty of our region would be catastrophic. The Victorian viaducts, the wildlife, the sanctuary it gives people of all ages for walking, cycling, horse riding, running. Days with families spent & enjoyed. The famous Red Kite walk, deer that amble around freely, we need the government to step in and review something that isn't needed.

attributes.action: Protect Mountain Hares in England under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981
attributes.background:
Create provision for Mountain Hares under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981
Section 1- Animals
Schedule 5 - Animals Which Are Protected and 
Schedule 6 - Animals which may not be Killed or Taken by Certain Methods.
For the protection of Mountain Hares (Lepus timidus) in England
attributes.additional_details:
Mountain Hares are now protected in Scotland, however within England they are not. 
There is currently a population within the Derbyshire Peak District  they exist in an isolated vulnerable population,with no potential for inward migration of other hares. These animals face decline due to site pressures, but also trapping in snare and other traps used by the grouse and game industry. Without better protection, the hares face even greater declines and possibly being lost from England once again.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/577569

attributes.action: Enforce the recycling of bottles and cans
attributes.background: Introduce legislation that bans the sale of non refundable drinks containers
attributes.additional_details:
Litter spoils our enjoyment of the countryside and can be harmful for wildlife and people.
Bottles and cans form a significant part of litter in the UK. We need  a Deposit Return Scheme, backed up by the Government.
For example; the Swedish model which is inshrined into law, uses a specially purposed organisation.
In 2018, Environment Secretary Michael Gove said “It is absolutely vital we act now.” If it was urgent then, it is even more so now.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/550260

attributes.action: Restore the ban on Neonicotinoids.
attributes.background:
Follow the Wildlife Trusts report on Reversing the Decline of Insects in the UK, starting with restoring the ban on Neonicotinoids.
Tough new standards should be introduced on the use of pesticides, and support should be put in place to help farmers follow insect friendly practices.
attributes.additional_details: Only the Government has the power to ban the use of these chemicals in the UK, and the Tory manifesto promised not only support for the environment, but support for British farmes too. This is something that can do both of those at once.

attributes.action: BAN SUPER TRAWLERS FROM BRITISH WATERS
attributes.background: WE WANT THE GOVERNMENT TO BAN SUPER TRAWLERS FROM PLUNDERING OUR WATERS AND KILLING OUR SEALIFE WITH THEIR OVERSIZED NETS CATCHING  ANYTHING AND EVERYTHING IN THEIR PATH
attributes.additional_details:
Supertrawlers the length of 14 fishing boats spent almost 3,000 hours touring protected waters around the British coast in 2019, scooping up thousands of tons of fish from sites designed to preserve marine wildlife.
They are making a mockery of UK protected seas

attributes.action: End all imports of Brazilian soy in the United Kingdom.
attributes.background: Deforestation in the Amazon rain forest is at a 12 year high. Much of this deforestation is because of clearance for soy farming. It is therefore vital to send a message out that we do not tolerate the destruction of one of the most precious wildlife sanctuaries on Earth.
attributes.additional_details: The Amazon rain forest is home to an incredible array of flora and fauna and also to many indigenous tribes of South America. It is also a vital carbon sink for the planet. Life on Earth cannot afford to lose the protection from global heating that this rain forest gives us. Follow the example of France and end the import of Brazilian soy to make the Brazilian government protect this vital part of our biosphere, for the sake of all life on Earth.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/553003

attributes.action: The government to ban the sale of fireworks to the general public,
attributes.background: To ban all sale of fireworks to the general public. Only coordinated displays who hold a licence will be able to hold a display. The licence looking at area, impact on local wildlife and residents. With options of silent fireworks or light displays as another option.
attributes.additional_details: The impact is causing emotional distress to all parts of society from elderly, soldiers or military with PTSD. I’m past on local wildlife and people loosing family pets

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/319891

attributes.action: Allow OUTDOOR areas of zoos, animal parks etc to re-open with social distancing.
attributes.background: To once again allow OUTDOOR areas of zoos, aquariums, wildlife parks and animal welfare charities to remain open and generate vital income with the assurance that robust cleaning regimes, mask wearing and social distancing measures are in place as is the case in public parks and outdoor spaces.
attributes.additional_details: Animal care/feeding/treatment/upkeep continues during a pandemic and the need to generate income is critical to survival. Zoos play a vital role in conservation in the UK and around the world. Institutions spend millions annually funding conservation that helps to preserve the habitats and numbers of critically endangered animals. This crucial conservation and zoo animals lives have once again been put under threat by the re-closure of zoos with many again facing closure due to lack of income.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/323881

attributes.action: Silent only fireworks on sale in the UK
attributes.background: Limit the sale of fireworks that emit noise to those holding organised displays, allow noise free fireworks ONLY to be sold to the general public
attributes.additional_details: Many people and animals suffer discomfort and sometimes terror during the weeks leading up to and the weeks beyond bonfire night. Each and every year they seem to get louder and the period of time they are used extends, by removing the sound, you are creating a better environment for all, human, domestic pets, agricultural animals and wildlife.

attributes.action: End Deer Culls in Royal Parks
attributes.background: Make it illegal to cull deer by shooting in Royal Parks
attributes.additional_details: Shooting deer on Royal Parks grounds causes suffering not only to the deer, but to the wildlife populations in the surrounding environment. Royal Parks should not be using their grounds to raise deer and then sell them for meat. They should adopt humane methods of managing deer populations- or phase them out completely.

rejection.details:
Royal Parks is now independent of the UK government, so decisions about operational matters such as the culling of deer is a matter for the Royal Parks, not the Government or House of Commons.

You could contact the Royal Parks directly to raise your concerns about the deer culls: https://www.royalparks.org.uk/about-us/contact-us

attributes.action: Only sell fireworks with a low noise level to the public
attributes.background: Set a noise limit to protect the public and wildlife only allow fireworks to be sold to the public for silent or low noise fireworks and allow displays and events to use loud noise level fireworks
attributes.additional_details: To protect wildlife pets and people with ptsd

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/549758

attributes.action: Make all fireworks silent.
attributes.background: Legislate to make all fireworks silent.  Fireworks don't need to make loud noises to be enjoyed.  The natural "whoosh" of a rocket or Catherine Wheel is fine, but remove the artificial pop, bang, explosion from all fireworks sold in the UK.
attributes.additional_details: Many of the problems with fireworks would be solved if they were silent.  This petition recognises the tradition of fireworks (eg Bonfire Night, weddings, Diwali), but seeks to minimize the impact on wildlife, farm animals, domestic pets, horses, and late night disturbance.

attributes.action: Ban the sale of Fireworks to the general public.
attributes.background: Restrict the use of fireworks to those holding the correct Explosives Licences under current https://www.hse.gov.uk/explosives/licensing/index.htm requirements. such as public fireworks displays.
attributes.additional_details: Fireworks contain explosive materials and no limitations are made on the amount the general public can purchase, given the current and ongoing concerns of potential terrorism, the flagrant and continual misuse by minors being passed fireworks by barely older (Adult) teens, the issues caused by personal public displays to wildlife (Wild and Domestic) and those suffering PTSD having served their country is just NOT acceptable!

attributes.action: Allow Zoos and Wildlife attractions to remain open and classify as public spaces
attributes.background: Zoos and Wildlife attractions such as safari parks should NOT be classified in the same category as cinemas/bowling alleys which means they have to shut in Covid Lockdowns. Zoos are essentially outdoor parks and by them remaining open with social distancing they can continue to operate financially.
attributes.additional_details:
Zoos provide conservation and science development with research but also provide a valuable mental health outlet for many people to explore and understand nature. These institutions require many funds to operate which even if they can open in a limited capacity helps them continue to fund the upkeep of the animals without being an additional burden on government grants.

cinemas and bowling alley entertainment is indoors but zoos are mainly outdoors so classification should be different.

attributes.action: Support zoos, wildlife parks and rehabilitation centres financially in Nov 2020
attributes.background: With a new lockdown starting from 5 Nov 2020, I urge the government to provide financial support to all zoos, wildlife parks and wildlife rehabilitation centres to ensure these places can continue their vital work for endangered species and animals in need of care due to injuries or ill health.
attributes.additional_details: Zoos, wildlife parks and wildlife rehabilitation centres have taken a significant financial impact during the first lockdown. These places provide vital contributions to prevent the extinction of endangered species, to help injured and orphaned wildlife and to educate about our natural world, on which we all rely. Please provide the necessary financial support to ensure these businesses can continue to provide the care for the animals during the 2nd lockdown and the following low income months.

attributes.action: Plant more hedgerows and trees after ripping them out for new housing estates.
attributes.background:
Ensure that any hedgerow or trees that are ripped up for new housing developments, are replaced and planted nearby.
Too many wildlife habitats are being ripped out and concreted over, soon there will be many species struggling to survive or extinct.
attributes.additional_details:
Replacing the trees and hedgerows nearby means species can thrive, aswell as having new housing for the growing population.
Birds will have habitat to return to to build nests, along with other wildlife that relies on hedges and trees to reproduce and live.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/549689

attributes.action: Demand Government declares an Ecological Emergency
attributes.background: Alarmed by David Attenborough's recent BBC documentary 'Extinction: The Facts'? Our living world, our web of life support, is dying. Demand our government urgently addresses this issue, declares an Ecological Emergency, and charts a credible path towards ecological recovery, at home and globally.
attributes.additional_details:
1) Attenborough documentary https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/m000mn4n/extinction-the-facts
2) The Convention on Biological Diversity report states that "Biodiversity is declining at an unprecedented rate, and the pressures
driving this decline are intensifying. None of the Aichi Biodiversity Targets will be fully met"
https://www.cbd.int/gbo/gbo5/publication/gbo-5-spm-en.pdf
3) WWF Living Planet Report states that 68% of wildlife has gone since 1970 https://livingplanet.panda.org/en-gb/

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do to tackle the ecological emergency. 
	
You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Object to the five tower gas generated plant that is to be built on Weaver Vale
attributes.background: The five tower gas generator plant being built on green belt land in Runcorn and causing more pollution.
attributes.additional_details: Runcorn is already heavily polluted for a small town, we need to think of our environment, noise pollution, gas emissions, affecting the local wildlife.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. Local planning issues are the responsibility of your local council.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:

https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

Calling-in a planning decision

Once an application is made for the development to take place, all local residents have the right to request that a planning application be ‘called in’ by the Department for Housing, Communities and Local Government. This means that it will assess the planning application against certain criteria and decide if a full inquiry is needed. For more information, including the criteria and how to request the call in of a planning application, see:
 
http://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/SN00930/SN00930.pdf 

You could also contact your local MP, who may wish to request the decision is called in if they agree with you. You can use this page to find out who your local MP is and how to contact them:
 
http://www.parliament.uk/mps-lords-and-offices/mps/ 


If you want the UK Government or Parliament to take action, for example to amend the legislation and policy framework which governs planning and development decisions taken by local authorities, you could start a new petition specifically asking for that action.

attributes.action: Build a network of pathways nationwide for wildlife and people.
attributes.background: These should be in suitable places to be life-enhancing for people and wildlife.
attributes.additional_details: It would make people happier, healthier and be better for the environment.

rejection.details:

You could start a petition calling for the Government to provide a fund for councils to build paths.

attributes.action: Lead the world in massively reducing our meat consumption accross the UK
attributes.background: The Government needs to recognise the environmental impact of animal agriculture (especially beef production) and make steps to reduce it. More sustainable backyard farming should be encouraged and farms should have a cap on beef production encouraging smaller back yard farming for self sustaining.
attributes.additional_details: Animal agriculture also has a huge impact to human life. The crisis in Yemen is a preventable tragedy considering we have enough land to feed the planet if we reduce our meat consumption. Millions of Yemen's population are at risk of dying from malnutrition including children and pregnant or lactating women. On top of this, deforestation in the Amazon and other rainforest effect humans and wildlife habitats alike. To not address this issue is to persue financial gain over human beings lives.

rejection.details:

attributes.background: Illegal immigrants are flooding the UK and not sent back. Thought under EU rules your supposed to stop off at the first safe country
attributes.additional_details: Illegal immigrants are putting the local councils under pressure to build thousands of homes everywhere. We won't have any green belt woodlands or countryside left. Wildlife animals habitats will be destroyed and pushed to extinction. They adding to the population of the UK. They are not contributing anything to the UK and are putting a strain on the NHS etc

attributes.action: Enforce the littering and social distancing laws to protect our natural spaces
attributes.background: Since lockdown restrictions have started to lift, groups of people are gathering in natural spaces, forests, parks, beaches and areas of outstanding natural beauty, discarding their litter mindlessly. We want the government to enforce the social distancing and littering laws to protect our nature.
attributes.additional_details: This behaviour is a danger to wildlife. It is unsightly and ruins views, river walks, countryside, beaches and other areas of outstanding natural beauty. Littering encourages and Increases negative behaviour. It reduces people’s sense of well-being, creates lawlessness and encourages greater criminal behaviour. Areas degraded by rubbish attract disease. Removal costs councils millions of pounds each year while the packaging and fast-food industry who create the problem are not held to account.

rejection.details:
The Government is responsible for passing legislation defining offences relating to littering and Covid-19 restrictions, but enforcing this is a matter for the police, not the Government or House of Commons.

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Increase penalties, enforcement and education to tackle littering & fly tipping: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/324488

Introduce heavy fixed penalties starting at £1000 minimum for littering: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/334297

The Government has also announced that it is imposing further restrictions on social gatherings, and will support Local Authorities and police forces to respond to breaches of COVID-19 Secure guidelines: https://www.gov.uk/government/news/coronavirus-covid-19-what-has-changed-9-september

attributes.action: Implement Vehicle Registration Printed on Drive-Thru Packaging
attributes.background:
There is a huge amount of littering from Drive-Thru packaging that has been a massive issue for many years and it needs to be looked into as it is continuous and by issuing fines could combat this litter.
This has an obvious negative effect on the environment, wildlife and is an absolute eye sore.
attributes.additional_details: With the government putting pressure on to fast food restaurants to implement Vehicle Registrations on packing where fines can be issued to individuals can act as a big deterrent.

attributes.action: Petition Nicola Sturgeon & Scottish Government to open Scottish Zoos immediately
attributes.background: Zoos are vital to conservation of our wildlife, with extensive rehoming & breeding programmes for endangered animals. The government have suggested they may be able to reopen from 15th July which risks them losing more vital funding for the animals. They should be allowed to open immediately.
attributes.additional_details: With businesses such as clothing retailers being allowed to reopen now, garden centres opened up & pubs & restaurants being discussed with outdoor spaces, it makes no sense to keep our Zoos closed. They are predominantly outdoor spaces who can easily adhere to social distancing rules. The government are prioritising human needs before animal welfare & conservation & need to address this immediately. We need our zoos & they need us.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government aren't responsible for the issue you raise. This is a matter for the Scottish Government.

Since you started your petition, zoos in Scotland have been allowed to reopen.

attributes.action: Allow zoos, animal and wildlife parks, and aquaria to re-open ASAP.
attributes.background: The example of Chester Zoo is all the example needed. They have made arrangements already to safeguard visitors, similar to retail outlets and other venues which are able to open. These are outdoor spaces, already identified as posing less risk to people than enclosed venues.
attributes.additional_details: The HSE could assist by certifying visitor hygiene and distancing arrangements having been put in place. Additionally hygiene at such venues is already high on the agenda due to prevention of other dangers such as ecoli and staphylococcus. If they are forced to start euthanising animals in order to survive, it'll be a heartbreaking situation and possibly one that some wildlife will not recover from. It will also be contrary to the fantastic conservation work championed by this great country.

attributes.action: Increase fines for littering and support a clean up campaign

attributes.action: Ban the sale and use of single use barbecues, for the sake of UK nature.
attributes.background:
The Wareham Forest blaze of May 202 is believed to be one of the most devastating forest and heath fires in Dorset in living memory.
The loss to wildlife was immense, and has pushed some species to the brink of extinction.
Single use barbecues must be banned immediately.
attributes.additional_details:
Dorset & Wiltshire Fire and Rescue Service, whose crews from all 50 fire stations from across the service attended the incident at some point over the last week, said 220 hectares – the size of over 230 football pitches – of forest and heathland has been destroyed.
It started on Monday, May 18 through 'social activity' – discarded barbecues, campfires and glass bottles were found at the site.
This incident highlights how devastating and resource intensive heath and forest fires are.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban Disposable Barbecues.
attributes.background: Please ban disposable barbecues.
attributes.additional_details:
Year after year we have terrible fires in our National Parks caused by careless use of disposable barbecues and badly managed camp fires.

 They have a devastating impact on our wildlife, cost hundreds of man hours and put our fire service in danger while they fight them. 
Last year we had fires in Moray, Greater Manchester, Winter Hill in Lancashire, and Ilkley Moor in West Yorkshire to the Vale of Rheidol in Ceredigion, and the Ashdown Forest in Sussex. 

2020 has already seen fires in areas like the Peak District, Wareham Forest,  Kilpatrick Hills, West Dunbartonshire.......

Surely the only sensible answer is to ban them in all areas where there is peat and valuable wildlife.

Please sign this petition, and ask your friends and family to do so as well. 
Thank you.
